body:
@ngupta23, short comments on first read:
* the issue you describe is not a bug, since you're not describing a discrepancy between expected/contracted functionality and actual functionality. You're actually commenting on what higher-order algorithm `ForecastingGridSearchCV` should implement in your opinion, and a discrepancy between that and the status quo.
* I agree we may want to carefully think about, and then document expected/contracted behaviour. There is lack of proper documentation of intended "should" here.
* I'm not sure I agree with your "should" state here. This would lead to two different algorithms being implemented, depending on the specific implementation of the wrapped estimator, not just on the type. I think dispatch-on-concrete, as opposed to dispatch-on-type, should be avoided.

rename.from: [BUG] Refit with ForecastingGridSearchCV when using a Grid Search based forecasters may not use "best hyperparameters"
rename.to: Refit with ForecastingGridSearchCV when using a Grid Search based forecasters may not use "best hyperparameters"

body:
Hi @fkiraly 

Definitely, more documentation on this would be nice. It was definitely not what I was expecting and would not have figured that out unless I was looking deeper into the code. 

And I agree that if that if this was intentionally done this way, then this is not a bug.

That being said, is there a way to do what I am asking in sktime right now or is it planned?

Thanks!

>That being said, is there a way to do what I am asking in sktime right now or is it planned?

That depends entirely on what you mean by "what I am asking", but I guess not.
Though I might also contest whether what you are asking is the behaviour we'd ultimately want.

Generally, I think one takeaway of this is that we may want to think carefully about how to document our higher order algorithms, since the devil is in the detail, and the expected/actual may differ if it is not properly written up somewhere.
Any opinions, @mloning?

@ngupta23 Having looked into this a bit more, I agree that this it not a bug and indeed what I would expect to happen - similar to what I'd expect to happen if I'd put a `GridSearchCV` into a `GridSearchCV` object in scikit-learn. 

If you do not want to run nested CV, you can just use temporal CV and optmise over the entire parameter grid: 
```python
from sktime.forecasting.all import *
from sklearn.model_selection import GridSearchCV
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestRegressor

y = load_airline()
fh = np.arange(1, 13)  

y_train, y_test = temporal_train_test_split(y, test_size=len(fh))

param_grid = {"regressor__n_estimators": [200, 300], "window_length": [12, 15]}

cv = SlidingWindowSplitter(
    initial_window=int(len(y_train) * 0.5),
    start_with_window=True,
)
regressor = RandomForestRegressor()
forecaster = ReducedRegressionForecaster(regressor, strategy="recursive")
gscv = ForecastingGridSearchCV(forecaster, cv=cv, param_grid=param_grid, verbose=1)
gscv.fit(y_train)
gscv.best_params_
```

I agree that we need to better document this. I'm also not sure what works better empirically, or what is being used more often in practice.

@fkiraly Thanks for the feedback on this topic. 
@mloning , Thanks for the alternate code. Let me try this out and get back in case there are any further questions. If this works as expected, it might be good to document this in the forecasting example notebook.

Hi @mloning , Thank you for the alternate code for `ReducedRegressionForecaster`. I verified that this alternate (without using `GridSearchCV` in the regressor) works great when using `scikit-learn` based regressors.

However the issue still exists with AutoARIMA since it is essentially an intelligent Grid Search. Do you have an alternate that works for `AutoARIMA` as well?
@ngupta23 if you do not want to use AutoARIMA, why not use simply ARIMA with a pre-defined grid for hyper-parameters?

I was afraid of that :). There are just too many hyperparameter combinations to try with the base ARIMA from `statsmodels`. Let me try it out anyway to see what can be done. Thanks again for your guidance on this.
